comments.commentBody:
Trump was more than just an unconstrained plurality. AS the field narrowed down, he remained dominant. He was rebellion against all of them, starting with more-of-the-same Bush, but finally every one of them. That is why those trying to sound like moderate sensible Republicans like Kasich got nowhere against him.

Senator Sanders was also a rebellion. It was more sane than Trump, but it was rebellion all the same. It was defeated by status quo.

Bush might have done the same as Hillary, except that he was so very bad as a candidate that even a $100 million head start and all possible insider support could not save him.

Hillary was more effective among Democrats than was Bush among Republicans. However, by putting down the rebellion among Democrats, she gave the rebellion side to Republicans. That is how Trump gets away with all he does, that is his cover.

I learned long after I left the university that the differences between different schools was not reflected in ratings, or even in college guides. I also learned that different schools will suit different students. One may very well need a college education to even begin to choose the proper college.

I also learned that some students will learn, no matter what they do, and that some will not learn, no matter what they do. The school makes only a little difference for either of those groups, although more for the former. The difference matters most for the majority in the middle, so more effort should be spent on those students. But it is very difficult to match the student to the college.

There are other things that I have learned about colleges, like you may not learn what you learned in college until many years afterwards, that what you get from a class may not be what the class is about, and that the path you choose may not be the path you are ultimately led to.

If all this seems confusing, I will end with one experience I had. The best discussion about how to choose a college came when I took my niece to discuss how she should choose with a professor I know. I would recommend that any college-bound student try to do that.

My mother and I took the hour-ish train ride from Rome to Spoleto, rented a car and spent a week exploring this beautiful area in fall 2013. Our home base was the organic stone farm agriturismo Localita al Piano, whose American-Italian owners grow heritage fruits, make goats milk cheese, and lead forest foraging walks. We made day trips to Norcia - quiet and small, with memorable wild boar's heads - the source of the famous salumi - decorating storefronts; to beautiful, historic Assisi, brimming with excitement as it prepared to host the new Pope, who had chosen their namesake saint's name as his own; to tiny Spello, another quintessential hilltop village like so many in the valley; and many trips into Spoleto, a large hilltop city, home of the famous music festival and to Roman ruins, gorgeous vistas, the rebuilt acquaduct, the duomo ... a living town, not glamorous, a little worn down, but wearing every one of its hundreds of years of history one on top of the other. And, unlike Rome and Florence at that time of year (September), none of these places were remotely overwhelmed with tourists, though Assisi is certainly more tourist destination than *normal* town.

As a professor, I am always amazed how much influence is wielded among public college administrators by the rankings of this magazine. Most academics don't read it and writing for it would do nothing for your academic reputation and promotion, but I have heard presidents demand that 'their' college should have an improvement in the rankings as a top goal for the year. What a sad case of the tail wagging the dog.

After a long academic career involving a small Christian college, a large state university, an elite liberal arts college, two Ivies, the City University of New York, and universities in Europe, I have found that the good students are equally good wherever you go. It is fair to say that elite institutions generally have a higher proportion of good students than less elite ones. What is more important is the self-assuredness of elite institutions whose faculty feel much freer to do what they consider to work well, while administrators at the lesser institutions don't want to give their faculty that freedom.

As a long time Penn State alumnus I feel compelled to support this principled student who clearly is the adult in the room. Much of the vitriol from some PSU alumni and others reflects the raging hyper-partisanship we see in so many aspects of our society. It doesn't matter if children were raped on Paterno's watch in his facilities by his right-hand man, the tribe must be defended and football (the game, of which I enjoy) must continue at all costs. The consequences of this mindset is plain to see for anyone who is willing to look. I hope we come to our senses soon.

Aaaaaaaaaaaah, because he was in charge.  Are you sure you are putting importance, value, and accomplishment where they belong? As far as, "It is convenient to blame a dead guy;" Really? For some people it is easy to have an opinion on things that don't affect them. However, I think most people blamed him when he was alive. I certainly did. Why would that stop at his death? Ya wanna honor him? Build a statue on your coffee table.
...and let me guess, "paterno.com" will give a "fair and balanced" portrayal of this issue. Sounds about right.

Here is a simple rule I follow: if she is paying tuition she has more right to ownership than the largest donor. Good luck with your sense of ownership and entitlement. In your pride for this school, you would paint over the tarnish. You know, ignore it. Win a football and if some young people's lives are traumatized, Hey, that's just collateral damage. Real nice. Davis 1- Small minded alumni (yes. Not all) - Forfeit.

If I remember correctly, the raison d'etre of a university is to teach students, to provide them with the skills to reach out and become the future. Until then, the risk in life is entirely theirs, and, in this world, there's an awful lot of risk. Alumni, living in the past, don't share that risk and are more secure in their present. You're job is to support your university to foster current students and the next generation of leaders, not mindless robots to rah-rah-rah at the next game of gladiator. If you demand of students unflinching mindless obedience to superiors and an institution, then perhaps you should have gone to joined the military. Bravo to Ms. Davis for using her mind, showing future leadership, and doing her university proud.

huh??  Paterno was a hero??? That's laughable.  He was a coach in a dangerous extra-curricular sport....nothing more...and a case could be made he wasn't very good at that.  He inherited a good program, with little competition in his state, had a few great years, he watched 100s of kids get hurt.  Hero is the last thing I'd call him.
And when there are public celebrations of these other alleged enablers of child rape, there should also be a debate.

I don't think that Penn State is alone in that type of treatment though.  People want to single out Penn State and those who follow them as some kind of cult, but look around the country at the places like Alabama, Texas, Nebraska.  It is the same thing.  Football is big everywhere you go and if something like this happened at one of these institutions we would be hearing the same criticisms about Football ruling the university.
He knew but he brought his own kids around Sandusky and his grandkids after that? The guy had everyone fooled.  That's what pedophiles do.

Forty years takes us to 1976. The date an alleged victim who did not show up for the trial claimed years after the trial that he was molested by Sandusky, told Paterno, and was rebuffed. His claim included testimony that he yelled in the shower room when it happened, and at least half a dozen other boys noted his cry.  All this at a football camp that in 1976 had no group showers--campers were sent to their dorm rooms for private showers. Yet  we should take this claim at face value as "very safe, indeed" proof Paterno knew? Somebody besides Paterno fans are living in a bubble here.
Don't think it was cowardice.  It was self interest.

From what I remember of the reportage at the time, Paterno was informed of Sandusky's crimes by at least one school official and did nothing for years. Sandusky was a saint, like all the 87 Catholic priests in the Boston area who were found to have spiritually/psychologically/sexually hurt and changed the course of over 1000 children's lives; but were moved and not removed by Cardinal Law.(who, himself, was rescued and sent to a plush post at the Vatican where he remains. Paterno is Cardinal Law.

See 'Spotlight', Academy Awarded, on Netflix, which is a compelling story about the four 'Spotlight' team reporters at the Boston Globe who shined a spotlight on the whole, deranged, corrupt system.

Shame on the continued Penn State worshippers of football over children.
You are very brave to confront and let go of your friend. Part of the problem is that supporters of HRC do not confront the Trumpinions at the local level. Touche and thank you

Perhaps a little cherishing and doing everything you could for those students considered not so smart might have a far greater impact than feeding broccoli to only broccoli lovers.  There are a few intellectually gifted students.  Most of the rest of us are a product of our wildly varying upbringings and our k-12 education.  What we bring to our first freshman class is not, depending on the skill and dedication of the faculty, what we leave with.

About as elitist a response as I can possibly imagine.  You should look into the Meyerhoff Scholars program the op-ed piece mentions; you will find they have done an incredible job of creating the intellectually community that you consider an "impossibility" at a school like UMBC.  University education would be much better off if they all were as passionate about undergraduate education as UMBC has demonstrated they are.  And at a cost that is about half that of the schools you mentioned.

Your actual experience of the institutions you dismiss is probably very limited.  There is an intermediate stratum of colleges and universities, to which UMBC belongs, where the actual percentage of intellectually engaged students ranges from 20-50%.  Nearly any "Nationally Ranked" university under the USNWR scheme is likely to have a community of real scholars at least as large as Swarthmore's, and, yes, they do find each other.

The most important resource in college is one fellow students. An 18-21 yr old mind is capable of acquiring only so much knowledge. What one develops in college are
1) intellectual interest
2) good study habits
3) good habits of reasoning and argumentation

These are almost impossible to acquire in a vacuum. Furthermore, they can't be instilled by a teacher. One must participate in a culture of learning. This requires a focused, intelligent community.

What distinguishes schools like Swarthmore and Penn and wesleyan for schools like UMBC is that at the former about 90% of the students are highly intelligent and focused and at the latter only about 12% are that way. Those 12% maybe be just as smart as the students at the more elite schools, but they are far fewer in number, which makes an intellectual community an impossibility. Certainly schools like UMBC will have a bunch of motivated students who can basically do it all on their own. Kids like that can go anywhere. Schools like Cornell and Tufts and Haverford and Brown and great for very intelligent kids who are not fully committed to education. By being around other highly intelligent kids, those kids become more interested in intellectual development.

Jerry, Either you have have missed Krugman's critical comments of Obama or have chosen to ignore them. He has been on a number of occasions. He has even been critical on his own previous comments when the passage of time has shown him to be incorrect. This is a sign of honest reporting. As for attacking Bernie, he was legitimately critical of a number of Bernie's policy claims. If Bernie had a better organization around him, he might have been able to respond in an effective way or modified his positions (btw, I voted for Bernie). As for the way you begin your comment with "What a joke", that is just condescension! It is difficult to seriously believe that you have anything resembling an open mind.

Yes, Jerry. Bernie Sanders lost the election because big bad Paul Krugman poisoned everyone's minds against him. And not at all because a majority of Democratic primary voters found him wanting.

No offense to our host, but I'd be shocked if more than one in ten Americans even knew who he was.
Actually, it is not highly probable that Hillary will lose. Five Thirty Eight has the probability that Hillary will win at 61.3%.

What a joke. The DNC organs like the Wash Post and the NY Times have been pro-Trump??? They have been as non-partisan as Krugman.

This election is about one thing: the desire for change.

Krugman has, in fact, been extremely beneficial to Trump.
In attacking Bernie, he said no change is possible, and Hillary is great because she realizes this.

On the issue of inegalitarianism, he has said she shouldn't worry about this, but focus on identity politics--horizontal inegalitarianism or how blacks and women do worse than white men--with no apparent improvement under Obama. In fact since Black Lives Matter arose in 2015, not 2007. they clearly are saying things got worse under Obama and we should vote Republicam

And for eight years, Krugman never really called on Obama to change anything, and never told him he was creating great anger by his awful policy. Instead he told Obama he was one of the great Presidents. Krugman had it right in January 2009, but just gave it up because he wanted to be ABC's man and ABC needed a spokesman for Obama with no subtle nuances.

He just criticizes Trump, never suggesting that Hillary can work with Congress as Trump can and all in a way that suggests he will introduce change--and change that is dangerous to Wall Street and Westchester.

Now when it is highly probable that Hillary will lose he says is all the fault of the pro-Trump Wash Post and NYT--not Obama. Clinton, or himself.

It clearly is a time for an end to an era.

Thanks for bringing up the issue of these useless and in fact "dangerous" rankings. These ranking provide false information to families looking for a college for their children. They also pervert the decision making process in universities, I work at a large public university and our president and provost have become obsessed with the rankings and are making a number of decisions whose goal is solely to increase the US News Ranking. These decisions are at odds with what is best for our current students and for the long term health of the university. It reminds me of CEOs who do what ever is necessary to drive up stock prices, even when those decisions are not in the long term best interest of the company and its employees.
Rankings do not reflect the experiences of students and the quality of education. Most of the highly ranked universities do not value undergraduate education and teaching, yet parents wrongly assume that the rankings reflect the quality of education their children will receive.
Parents do deserve information about educational quality. BUT the current ranking system does not provide that and worse it has greatly perverted how universities are run.
Thanks for the suggestions!

We are lucky enough here in Portland to have the BBC World Service running almost all night on our local public radio station (OPB), so I use the "real thing" rather than a podcast for the same purpose.  Thanks to both BBC and OPB (which I support with membership donations).

I am with you on this Janet and have relied on listening to podcasts with one earbud when I experience the occasional night where my mind won't stop. Before the iphone I used a pillow speaker plugged into talk radio. The talk quells the thoughts and allows relaxation to transition into sleep. Thanks for the BBC tip!

I save the audio books for the car!

While my insomnia is not as severe as Ms. Kennedy’s and was partially resolved by a medication change, I still have some trouble. Interestingly, I have independently discovered roughly the same solution, only I use regular earbuds and just put one of them in the right ear, as I am mostly a side sleeper. If I wake up, I turn over and reverse the earbuds. Instead of audio books, I listen to BBC Podcasts (BBC.co.uk/podcasts). They have tons of them in many categories. I listen mostly to science and documentary ones, but there are many others in the arts, sports, business, and more. They are free (and free of commercial content), professionally presented by talented and informed people, and the accents seem to help as well (oddly enough). The only drawback is that I go to sleep within 15 minutes (the normal fall asleep time!), so have to do each podcast (30 to 60 min) two or three times to hear the whole thing.

I write to them once a year or so to thank the British people for paying their license fees and helping me not only to sleep, but to learn so much about the world and it’s people.

I will try Mr Ackerman’s podcast out of curiosity and add it to the mix. I have tried audio books, but while they work, I don’t find 15 minute bursts of a novel to be very satisfying. I now listen to them while I knit.

Agree entirely except no one will believe a declaration of victory. We have been thwarted beyond measure. Declaring defeat is in keeping with reality and will help keep us from engaging in another futile undertaking.
Then in a couple of years we can declare failure in Iraq, Libya and Syria. There is an aphorism " honesty is the best policy". Let's try that.

The next President will have a very good option in Afghanistan.

Get out.

Declare victory, and leave.

We are not served by anything we are doing there.

Al Qaeda is now many other places far more dangerous than the Afghan mountains it long ago left behind. ISIS is even worse, and has never been in Afghanistan. We are no fighting them in Afghanistan. We do not risk them going to Afghanistan when they are already in far more troublesome places.

It is a classic case of mission creep. Instead of leaving, we stay and fight on and on to now purpose, just because we are there and fighting.

"Credibility" is nonsense, an excuse when no other is available. We are credible because we have real power, and nobody doubts we are free to use it, far too much so.

We can't build a new Afghanistan, only Afghans can do that, and far too few are interested in building what we would want to help build anyway. We cannot save them from themselves.

Just go. We have stayed far too long for any good we are doing.

Sorry, cynical, but the plural of anecdote is not data. The Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank has done surveys about employment at US colleges and universities, and this is their latest report:
https://clevelandfed.org/newsroom-and-events/publications/economic-comme...

Interesting points covering 1987-2013—all measured as percentages of total employees--
* The widespread belief that administrative and management staff have increased is not true—not changed at all.
* Clerical/secretarial staff numbers have declined.
* Other professionals (IT, lawyers, librarians, etc.) have increased.
* Full-time faculty have decreased, as part-time faculty have increased.

One can conclude that, as public universities experienced a decrease in state support funding, more part-time adjunct faculty members have replaced full-time people to save money. Likewise, clerical staff numbers have decreased as more people do more of their own clerical tasks on their PCs, and secretaries are being shared by more people. The increase in other professionals is complex, perhaps because governments have increased reporting requirements, universities compete for students (= tuition $) by providing more amenities, student recruiting people have been hired, fundraising staffs have beefed up to draw more donations, etc.

That was originally supposed by Obama to be a much smaller and shorter proof of his willingness to fight. It got away from him. It now serves no purpose, not for the country, not even for his political position.
